title: Why Medieval Streets Were Open Sewers
description: A 60-second lesson on Why Medieval Streets Were Open Sewers.

hook.text: Medieval streets had a center channel called the 'kennel.' It carried human waste, dung, and slaughterhouse blood.

buildup.text: Without Roman sewers, cities used open gutters. Rain was the only flushâ€”dry summers meant festering waste.

discovery.text: Butchers, tanners, and dyers dumped toxins straight into rivers. Waterways downstream of cities were biologically dead.

twist.text: The rich walked elevated sidewalks or were carried above filth. Street stepping stones weren't for rainâ€”but sewage.

climax.text: This cycle lasted 1,000 years until industrialization made cities too dense to survive without engineered sanitation.

punchline.text: A thousand years of walking through sewage.

quiz.question: What purpose did stepping stones in medieval streets actually serve?
options: To keep pedestrians above the sewage running through street channels
To slow horse-drawn carriages at intersections
To mark property boundaries between buildings
